reviews.review_msg: Gerardo was a great professor! He is passionate about the material, which was contagious. We always went to class excited to talk about politics. Quite a few readings but flexible w/ due dates. I learned a lot in his class and he is a kind, caring, and compassionate professor who genuinely cares about his students success and well-being.

Enjoyed class and learned a lot. A lot of weekly writing, but the criteria were clear and this meant the workload was more spread out over the semester. Readings were heavy into sociology at the start, but became more interesting (for me) over time. His political ideology is apparent in class, but he is always open for dissenting views.

Had to take this 4 credit course as an elective to finish my degree. Honestly the WORST prof ever in SFU. Assign super low marks, grab on to every little detail to cut off your mark. Lecture is dry like dessert, its impossible to stay awake. Not allowed to come late, skip 3 class you fail the entire course. Critize your work in front of the class.
This is my final semester at SFU, and I can without a doubt say, HE IS THE WORST PROFESSOR I'VE EVER HAD. Seriously, if you don't have to take his classes... DON'T.

Unpopular in our class. Calls on students to answer specific questions in class, like high school.  Attendance policy harsh. In class work not particularly  interesting/relevant. Narrow focus on civil rights, few opportunities to explore  other movements. Weekly posts were not demanding. Not difficult but this course deserves better.

Very unorganized, and had to buy 3 books that were mandatory to use. He also forced students to attend seminars and said would fail (recieve N) if you skipped more than 3 classes. Lectures were boring and felt like they did not help a lot, most classes had a film to watch that did not feel relevant at times. Take this class with another prof.

He was super unorganized and seems like he didn't know what he was talking about half the time. Lectures and textbook readings were unrelated. First half of class from lecture and second half was spent watching a movie. Interesting, but he rarely asked about it on exams. Most people leave after the lecture part. Hated going to tutorials.

Lectures are confusing even if you have background knowledge - focus on the names he mentions and their theories. Midterm is much harder than the final b/c it covers more chapters. Tests are based on the textbook and a little on the lectures. Tutorials can be a drag b/c most students don't care abt the material, but participation is 15% so go.

Lectures are very confusing, and not essential to passing the course. He says "supplementing the chapter" yet you are left confused after going to class. Theres a movie every single lecture that are somewhat interesting, yet very little questions are asked on tests. Term paper is a joke, three drafts of non sense. Yet prof seemed really nice.

2 hour class, 1st hour is a lecture and 2nd is a film. Don't bother going to lecture, it's completely unrelated to the book. Just read the book and go to tutorial. Both midterm and final were multiple choice. There are some questions based off the films but you can usually find them online. Make sure to attend tutorials as it's worth 15%.
Not a good lecturer, its hard to follow his lectures as they are so boring and hes not that good at teaching. Take this class with a different prof

His lectures are quite dry and can often be confusing. He throws in a few jokes here and there but is often too quiet. Tests are a bit tough; harder than what you'd expect. Didn't learn much from his lectures. Read the textbook and go to tutorials and you're set.
Vague lecture notes
The lecture was really dry. On top of his dry lectures, he goes off topic and includes information that is not necessary for the midterm or the final.

incredibly interesting. Although his lectures can be slow paced, the lecture and course materials and incredibly informative and easy to link, but there are a lot of readings that require close analysis/time. He does discussion papers every week for a little bit of your mark, if you do them you will have a good understanding of course materials

Gerardo invests a great deal of energy and care into the quality of his classes. The intensity and pace of reading/writing assignments is demanding, but this ends up being very helpful for digesting material at a regular rate throughout the course. Excellent prof overall!
Very helpful and fair to students. Good sense of humour. Strong sense of justice & empathetic. Extremely interesting class topics, nice diversity. Is a professional and always on time.

Makes the lectures interesting with a mix of slides and films. Does skim through some material, so you'll need to go through the text thoroughly. Could do with more clarity with the synthesis. Multiple choice exams are fairly tough. Would have preferred written! Has a good sense of humour. Decent professor overall for a first year course.

He taught for one hour using brief slides, then used the second hour to watch a film. Lectures are helpful, but only skim what is needed for the exam. Attendance and write ups count a lot towards the grade. Don't skip tutorial or you will lose 2%. Exams are mostly fair, but a handful of questions are quite difficult. In the end, hard work pays off.

Made no sense. Lots of readings on classical theorists, yet exams based more on slides. He is organized & nice but like in prev. comment is confusing when he asks for something. Very strict, very old school. DO THE DISCUSSION AND RESPONSE ASSIGNMENTS if you want to increase your chances of passing, otherwise this class is suicide. Good luck.

Never have I felt so much as though I was walking on egg shells than in this class. While he can be nice, Gerardo tends to be quite one sided. I don't recommend that in a theory course. Other than that, his marking is pretty fair; what he requests out of his students is often incredibly vague. I wouldn't take upper level courses with him again.
He is a very good teacher! To pass the course you need to attend to the tutorials and read the book for the exam!
It is a demanding course, but if you are a hardworking student you should be fine. I thoroughly enjoyed taking his class.

class attendance required as the participation marks would be helpful to boost assignment marks. assignments are extremely hard. you get 13 weeks to complete 5 discussions and 5 responses. you do not have to hand in the week your assigned. It would be best to complete you 5 responses in first 5 weeks first, and leave discussions to last. =)

Otero is a solid prof- he IS old school and expects you to work really hard and spend 12 hrs/wk reading. He's a warm person and is super helpful if you ask, so ask! He has to be tough because it's a req'd course, and if you're lazy or a poor communicator then your grade will reflect that, but he'll tell you how to fix it for next the paper.
Fair marker but heavy courseload.  Readings are all good but Otero's interpretations are questionable. He is not Marxist as previous student claims. Nice guy generally but can be rude and dismissive.

He is organized with power point notes. His teaching style is ok. He is a very nice person, but he has strong marxist ideology. He is very proud to be mexican and he teaches mexican things whenever he can.

The first course I ever took in Sociology was with Otero. I would recommend you take courses with him because he is not only helpful but also his topics of lecturing are interesting and quite insightful.
No Comments
If you want to take this course, you better take it with Ann Travers.  350 is overly demanding for people with busy time schedule
